August 1918.2.10NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION-No. 66.Week ended 24th August, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS.Minelaying operations have been carried out in the North Sea and off the Belgian North Sea. coast.On 20th August, at 2 p.m., the Belgian Relief Ship " Gasconia " was torpedoed or mined when 2\ miles west of Rovaer (Norway).On 23rd August, at 1 a.m., four or five enemy Motor Boats attempted a reconnaissance Flanders of Dunkirk Roads, but were driven off by British and French patrols, assisted by land Area, defences. The French Destroyer " Obusier" claims to have sunk one Motor Boat. No damage or casualties were sustained by the Allied forces.The weather generally has not been favourable for flying, but in addition to reconnais-sances and patrols which have been carried out in various areas by R.A.F. machines work-ing with the Navy, the following raids have been made by machines from Dunkirk : Approximate weight of Date. In the course of aerial fighting during these raids three enemy machines were destroyed and three driven down out of control. One of our machines is missing.On the night of 19th August two of our aircraft left Mudros for a bombing raid on Mediter-Constantinople, but owing to thick weather, only one machine reached the objective, where ranean. bombs were dropped on and near the Admiralty. The other machine dropped bombs on Eregli and Rodosto, and both machines returned safely.On 20th August five machines from Taranto carried out an attack on Cattaro, and dropped a ton of bombs on submarine quarters and amongst shipping. All the machines returned safely.During the night of the 21st-22nd August our machines dropped three-quarters of a ton of bombs on Galata, causing great damage to buildings and hangars.(C 1358) Wt, - 50 8/18 H&S A On the same night half a ton of bombs was dropped on Nagara aerodrome and forts by British and Greek machines, and Chanak was also attacked,, considerable damage being done at both places. Two of the machines reached Constantinople where they dropped 500lbs. of bombs on military objectives. All machines returned safely except one which fell into the sea, the pilot being saved, but the observer drowned.Casualties. On 22nd August in Runswick Bay, a Motor Launch was blown to pieces by a torpedo ' which it was endeavouring to salve, three officers and seven men being killed.ATTACK UPON ENEMY SUBMARINES.1Submarines The number of large enemy submarines, of a type which operates further afield than operating, the North Sea, which were located during the week was again 12, included in which number were four of the " cruiser " type, one working in the vicinity of the Azores and the other three on the eastern seaboard of North America. There was a marked absence of activity in the English Channel and the Bay of Biscay, but of! the East Coast of England consider-able activity was experienced, especially between Flamborough and Holy Island, where an average of three boats were working throughout the week.Actions The following Table shows the number of actions between Allied craft and enemywith enemy submarines which are reported to have taken place in all waters during recent weeks submarines. an(j ^ nature 0f the craft which have been engaged ; and also the number of submarines which have been destroyed or lost to the enemy as the result of such actions : Week ended Week ended Week ended Week ended Aug . 3rd. " Umoolosi " has been damaged, off Ceylon, by a mine which must have broken adrift from the old field laid by the Raider " Wolf."MOVEMENTS OF ENEMY SHIPS.Merchant- During the week under review seven enemy merchant ships arrived at and eight men- sailed from Norwegian ports outside the Cattegat. No enemy ships have entered or left Eotterdam, but again one enemy steamship has arrived at Harlingen from the Rhine.FOREIGN NAVAL INTELLIGENCE. Russia.Very little reliable news has been received during the week, and the general situation -appears to remain unaltered.Both in the Archangel district and in the Far East we are awaiting reinforcements before commencing further operations.One battleship has been added to the Japanese Force on the Russian Pacific Coast. The Vice Admiral Commander-in-Chief of the Third Fleet is in supreme command, and is personally directing operations off the mouth of the Amur River.A British naval detachment, with guns, under Commodore D. T. Norris, R.N., is now on the Caspian, and it is hoped to form a small naval force by acquiring the two Russian gun-boats, and by mounting guns in merchant vessels.Information has been received that Russian mines have recently been laid in the Baltic, evidently with a view to sinking German ships. Negotiations were begun at Mariehamn on August 21st, between German, Swedish, and Finnish delegates, concerning the de-molition of the fortifications on the Aland Islands.Naval Staff.29$ August, 1918.
